bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 14, 1944

div1.p: Kean appreciates the copy of Reed's letter and photograph, although he is unable to identify anyone in the picture. He mentions a planned mural at a Cuban Military Hospital celebrating the conquest of yellow fever. After his death, his books will be donated to the University of Virginia.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 14, 1944

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Sept. 14/44

div1.p:
Mrs Kean asked me at breakfast
this morning if I had written to you
and I replied No, but I am going to do
so today- When the postman came an
hour later he brought me your letter
with the photos of Reeds New Years Eve
letter which I am glad to have-

As to the group with the Army ambulance
I cannot identify it. I do not think it
could have been taken at Camp Lazear
From the establishment of the camp Reed was
careful not to have any non-immunes
come around and no small boys would
have been allowed there mingling with
the patients- I think that the picture may
2
have a souvenir of Reed's first visit
to Cuba in May 1899 when he spent
a week down in the Island at Puerto
Principe- Truby in his book mentions it
in connection with his account of the case
of Patrick Smith which Wasdin insisted
was yellow fever altho. he saw the autopsy
with the Peyer's patches and other classical evi-
dences of typhoid - pp. 40 & 41. In your P. S.
your stenog make you speak of a Sibley stone
in the little building No.2 at Camp Lazear. I
think that quite probably they may have
had a Sibley stove, and they were light, handy
little cone shaped affairs used especially in connec-
tion with the Sibley tents and every quarter-
master had them in stock- They had
no bottom but the ground and a door
thru which the small sticks of wood were
fed to them- The small stove pipe went out
3
at the apex of the conical Sibley tent with a
provision to protect the canvas-

Did Sra Raquel Romero of Havana come
to see you in July? She is an artist who
had a contract to paint a mural for
a lecture room at the Military Hospital
at Marianao and had selected as her
subject the infection of mosquitoes by
Lazear and then the infection of the Amer-
ican nurse Miss Maas who died of it
in the experiments of Guiteras & Gorgas-
She was a very intelligent women who
spoke English and brought me a letter
of introduction from Dr Domingo Remos
She wanted to meet Mr. Cornwell and you
and had telegraphed to you at Rochester- I told
her where you were & she planned to go to
AC
K
Hot Springs on her way back to Havana
She saw Cornwell I think and got kind
advice from him- I hope she was able
to get to see you- She was very earnest and
energetic and had been to the Army
Medical Library- The Cuban Embassy were
helping her all they could-

I have been going over my old papers to
pick out a few to be deposited somewhere
when I die, an event which I have no
right to think distant since I had
my 84th birthday in June- No one of
my ancestors, so far as I can learn, has
ever stood off the grim Reaper that
long and I want to save Mrs Kean the
worry of having to make worrying decisions-
She tells me that you once told her to bun-
dle up and send to you any thing rela-
ting to the Y. F. Episode. My only son is not
Sept 14, 1944
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
a doctor and would have no use for
all this correspondence- But I cannot see-
that you would have use for it either as
the main bulk consists of letters from you
of which you have carbon copies with
some from Truby- I have several nice
letters from Andrus the year before he died
I have also many photographs which you have
sent me and you would not want duplicates.
I cannot imagine that at any time in the
future any man with your industry,
energy and gift for research and for
weighing and adjudicating facts will ever
come along to repeat the wonderful study
that you have made of the Y. F. Episode-
I wish that I could hope to see the conclu-
sions that you have arrived at put into
print- You must not put off for too long
the putting together of the bricks to build your edifice
6
I remember having exchanged some
letters with Dr. Harvey Cushsing about
his admirable Life of Sir Wm Osler-
I expressed regret that he could not
get it all in one volume, as people
just will not buy 2 volume biogra-
phies- He wrote that he knew that
was true, but that it would require
another year of work to compress his
material into one volume and he
could not spare another year from
the practice of his profession-

Some years after its publication however
he found a gifted woman who did
the job of compression into one volume
very well- Have you any suggestions
as to what I can do with my U S S?

I am praying that I may live to see a glorious
ending to this great war in which
the English speaking people are engaged
7
and a peace such as Tennyson foresaw
(in Locksley Hall)

“When the war-drum throbbed no longer, and
the battle flags were furl'd
In the Parliament of man, the Federation of the
World
There the common sense of most shall hold a fretful
realm in awe,
And the kindly earth shall slumber, lap't
in universal law”

But we will not wait for that consumma-
tion, for me to decide what to do with
my accumulation of papers, My good
friend Dr. Harry Clunous the Librarian of
the Alderman Library at the Univ. Va.
will give a home to some of my old books
to which I am attached, but I hesitate to
propose to make a dumping ground of his
five institution- So come on now and advise
AC
K
8
me what to do with my old papers
By the way I found the letters of Wal-
ter Reed that I was looking for-
But they had nothing to do with the
episode- One was at the beginning of
the Spanish War when he was in the
S. G. O. & I wanted to get sent to the
front- Another was when I was urging
him to be a candidate to succeed
Gen. Sternberg and the third was a
very humorous account of the attitudes
and claims of the various candidates
This I destroyed as it would do no good
to keep it and I am sure he did not
intend that I should do so-

Col. Siler who sees the Reeds occa-
sionally tells me that Blossom is now
all right and Mrs Reed who is 88 is
doing well- when you get time to write
to me do not fail to give me the news of Mrs Hench and your
mother & of the children-
